e4: I would not recommend changing to the new policy because, although it ensures truth-telling in earnings reporting, the associated risk of investors' incorrect adjustments and subsequent punishment seems more significant than potential benefits of switching. This might result in negative market reaction, reduced investor trust, and ultimately lower profits for the company.
e5: An ethical reporting policy should primarily prioritize honesty, transparency, and integrity. It should accurately represent financial information without intention to deceive or misinform stakeholders. Considerations such as consistency in application, relevance, materiality, and potential consequences of changes on investor trust and decisions are also crucial.
e6: Yes. I would ask them to provide data on how often investors adjust earnings estimates, and what their expectations are regarding the direction of such adjustments (i.e., how much downward adjustment can occur before shareholders begin to distrust management.)
